L1: # Agent Task
L2: 
L3: Task id: trappist1b-atmosphere
L4: Task title: JWST phase-curve evidence for an atmosphere on TRAPPIST-1 b
L5: Reference paper: Phase-curve Evidence for an Atmosphere on TRAPPIST-1 b
L6: Reference URL: https://arxiv.org/abs/2409.13036
L7: 
L8: ## Objective
L9: Read the report and produce all required JSON outputs that satisfy their schemas.
L10: 
L11: ## Inputs On Disk
L12: - Report: `input/report.md`
L13: - Schemas: in `schemas/`
L14: 
L15: ## Required Outputs
L16: - `output/study_overview.json` (schema: `schemas/study_overview.schema.json`)
L17: - `output/quantitative_findings.json` (schema: `schemas/quantitative_findings.schema.json`)
L18: - `output/claim_audit.json` (schema: `schemas/claim_audit.schema.json`)
L19: - `output/public_summary.json` (schema: `schemas/public_summary.schema.json`)
L20: 
L21: ## Constraints
L22: - Do not invent source facts; derive calculations only from values in the report.
L23: - Use line refs as `L<number>` where required.
L24: - Where quotes are required, copy exact report snippets.
L25: - For calculation outputs, line_refs must include every report line used for equations, constants, and numeric substitutions.
L26: - Use relative paths only.
L27: - Never use absolute paths.
L28: - Never use `..` in paths.
L29: - Write valid JSON only.
L30: 
L31: ## Completion
L32: Respond with a checklist of written output files.
L33: After the checklist, stop. Do not call more tools.

L1: # Structured Paper Report: Atmosphere of TRAPPIST-1 b from JWST Phase-Curve Data
L2: 
L3: ## Citation
L4: - Title: Phase-curve Evidence for an Atmosphere on TRAPPIST-1 b
L5: - Venue: arXiv preprint
L6: - Year: 2024
L7: - DOI: 10.48550/arXiv.2409.13036
L8: - Source URL: https://arxiv.org/abs/2409.13036
L9: 
L10: ## One-Paragraph Context
L11: TRAPPIST-1 b is an Earth-sized rocky planet on a very short, likely tidally locked orbit around an M dwarf. The key question is whether it retains any atmosphere under strong stellar irradiation. The study uses JWST MIRI phase-curve spectroscopy to jointly constrain day-night heat transport and atmospheric composition.
L12: 
L13: ## Study Design Snapshot
L14: - Instrument: JWST MIRI low-resolution spectroscopy over an orbital phase curve.
L15: - Observables: thermal phase variation and spectral structure around the 15 um CO2 band.
L16: - Inference workflow: retrieval models comparing atmosphere-free and atmosphere-bearing scenarios.
L17: 
L18: ## Cohorts and Scenarios
L19: 1. Observed system: one rocky exoplanet (TRAPPIST-1 b) with phase-resolved thermal spectra.
L20: 2. Null scenario: bare-rock, no-atmosphere model with minimal heat redistribution.
L21: 3. CO2-rich atmosphere scenario: atmosphere model with significant greenhouse gas absorption.
L22: 4. O2-rich atmosphere scenario: oxidized composition with weaker CO2 signature constraints.
L23: 
L24: ## Quantitative Findings
L25: | Metric | Retrieved/Preferred Value | Comparator | Interpretation |
L26: |---|---:|---:|---|
L27: | Dayside brightness temperature | 342 +/- 22 K | Bare-rock expectation from no-redistribution model | Day side is warm but not sufficient alone to prove a bare surface |
L28: | Heat transport efficiency (epsilon) | 0.19 (+0.23 / -0.14) | 0.0 for perfect no-atmosphere limit | Non-zero redistribution is favored |
L29: | Bond albedo upper bound | <0.08 | Higher-albedo reflective cases | Planet appears very dark in thermal-energy balance fits |
L30: | 15 um CO2 spectral band depth estimate | 96 ppm | Flat-spectrum null | Spectral structure is consistent with atmospheric absorption |
L31: | Joint fit likelihood ratio (atmosphere vs no atmosphere) | 7.4 | 1.0 baseline ratio | Atmosphere-bearing models better explain combined data products |
L32: | Preferred pressure scale in CO2-rich retrieval family | 0.3-1.0 bar | Near-vacuum branch | Moderate-pressure atmosphere family remains plausible |
L33: 
L34: ## Controls and Null/Conditional Results
L35: - A pure no-atmosphere model cannot simultaneously match both phase amplitude and spectral band behavior.
L36: - O2-rich atmosphere cases are not fully ruled out by current data.
L37: - Degeneracies between composition, clouds/hazes, and circulation assumptions remain significant.
L38: 
L39: ## Mechanistic Chain Proposed by Authors
L40: 1. Thermal phase offsets and amplitudes probe day-night energy redistribution.
L41: 2. A non-zero redistribution parameter implies transport beyond an immediate bare-rock reradiation limit.
L42: 3. Spectral structure near 15 um provides composition-sensitive evidence, especially for CO2-rich scenarios.
L43: 4. Joint constraints from phase curve and spectrum are stronger than either observable alone.
L44: 5. Remaining degeneracies motivate broader wavelength coverage and repeated observations.
L45: 
L46: ## Caveats and Threats to Validity
L47: - This is a single-planet study and does not establish atmospheric prevalence across all M-dwarf rocky planets.
L48: - Retrieval assumptions (circulation, opacity priors, cloud treatment) affect quantitative posteriors.
L49: - Stellar variability and instrument systematics can bias weak spectral features.
L50: - Night-side constraints are weaker than day-side constraints in the current dataset.
L51: 
L52: ## Practical Takeaway
L53: The dataset provides meaningful evidence against a strictly airless interpretation for TRAPPIST-1 b, but atmospheric composition and pressure remain uncertain enough that follow-up spectroscopy is essential.

L1: # Structured Paper Report: Atmosphere of TRAPPIST-1 b from JWST Phase-Curve Data
L2: 
L3: ## Citation
L4: - Title: Phase-curve Evidence for an Atmosphere on TRAPPIST-1 b
L5: - Venue: arXiv preprint
L6: - Year: 2024
L7: - DOI: 10.48550/arXiv.2409.13036
L8: - Source URL: https://arxiv.org/abs/2409.13036
L9: 
L10: ## One-Paragraph Context
L11: TRAPPIST-1 b is an Earth-sized rocky planet on a very short, likely tidally locked orbit around an M dwarf. The key question is whether it retains any atmosphere under strong stellar irradiation. The study uses JWST MIRI phase-curve spectroscopy to jointly constrain day-night heat transport and atmospheric composition.
L12: 
L13: ## Study Design Snapshot
L14: - Instrument: JWST MIRI low-resolution spectroscopy over an orbital phase curve.
L15: - Observables: thermal phase variation and spectral structure around the 15 um CO2 band.
L16: - Inference workflow: retrieval models comparing atmosphere-free and atmosphere-bearing scenarios.
L17: 
L18: ## Cohorts and Scenarios
L19: 1. Observed system: one rocky exoplanet (TRAPPIST-1 b) with phase-resolved thermal spectra.
L20: 2. Null scenario: bare-rock, no-atmosphere model with minimal heat redistribution.
L21: 3. CO2-rich atmosphere scenario: atmosphere model with significant greenhouse gas absorption.
L22: 4. O2-rich atmosphere scenario: oxidized composition with weaker CO2 signature constraints.

  "id": "fc_073c6222a136b2710069907305e1008191b7a69ce24b3704d2",

  "arguments": "{\"file_path\":\"output/study_overview.json\",\"content\":\"{\\n  \\\"paper\\\": {\\n    \\\"title\\\": \\\"Phase-curve Evidence for an Atmosphere on TRAPPIST-1 b\\\",\\n    \\\"doi\\\": \\\"10.48550/arXiv.2409.13036\\\",\\n    \\\"publication_year\\\": 2024,\\n    \\\"domain\\\": \\\"exoplanet-atmospheres\\\",\\n    \\\"study_type\\\": \\\"observational-astronomy\\\"\\n composition.\\\",\\n  \\\"datasets_or_cohorts\\\": [\\n    {\\n      \\\"id\\\": \\\"trappist1b-phasecurve\\\",\\n      \\\"label\\\": \\\"TRAPPIST-1 b JWST MIRI phase-curve spectroscopy\\\",\\n      \\\"sample_size_or_observations\\\": \\\"One planet observed over an orbital phase curve with phase-resolved thermal spectra\\\",\\n      \\\"description\\\": \\\"Thermal phase variation and spectral structure around the 15 um CO2 band are measured with JWST MIRI low-resolution spectroscopy to infer atmospheric and heat-transport properties.\\\"\\n    },\\n    {\\n      \\\"id\\\": \\\"no-atmosphere-null\\\",\\n      \\\"label\\\": \\\"Bare-rock, no-atmosphere model (null scenario)\\\",\\n      \\\"sample_size_or_observations\\\": \\\"Model comparator for the same phase-curve dataset\\\",\\n      \\\"description\\\": \\\"An atmosphere-free interpretation assuming minimal heat redistribution is used as a baseline to test whether an airless surface can explain both the phase amplitude and spectral behavior.\\\"\\n    },\\n    {\\n      \\\"id\\\": \\\"co2-rich-retrieval\\\",\\n      \\\"label\\\": \\\"CO2-rich atmosphere retrieval family\\\",\\n      \\\"sample_size_or_observations\\\": \\\"Model family fit to phase-curve + spectrum\\\",\\n      \\\"description\\\": \\\"Atmosphere-bearing retrieval models with significant greenhouse gas absorption are compared against the null to assess whether CO2-related spectral structure and redistribution are supported.\\\"\\n    },\\n    {\\n      \\\"id\\\": \\\"o2-rich-retrieval\\\",\\n      \\\"label\\\": \\\"O2-rich atmosphere retrieval family\\\",\\n      \\\"sample_size_or_observations\\\": \\\"Model family fit to phase-curve + spectrum\\\",\\n      \\\"description\\\": \\\"Oxidized-composition atmosphere scenarios with weaker CO2 signature constraints are evaluated as alternative explanations that may not be fully excluded by the present data.\\\"\\n    }\\n  ],\\n  \\\"major_limitations\\\": [\\n    \\\"Single-planet study; does not establish prevalence across M-dwarf rocky planets.\\\",\\n    \\\"Retrieval assumptions (circulation, opacity priors, cloud treatment) affect posteriors.\\\",\\n    \\\"Stellar variability and instrument systematics can bias weak spectral features.\\\",\\n    \\\"Night-side constraints are weaker than day-side constraints in the current dataset.\\\",\\n    \\\"Degeneracies between composition, clouds/hazes, and circulation assumptions remain significant.\\\"\\n  ]\\n}\"}",
  "call_id": "call_X3OZ75kEHXJNqYtzjR7Bkmar",
  "name": "write_file",
  "parsed_arguments": null
}\n[tool-call]\n{
  "id": "fc_073c6222a136b2710069907305e1108191a05372874a3e1497",
  "type": "function_call",
  "status": "completed",
  "arguments": "{\"file_path\":\"output/quantitative_findings.json\",\"content\":\"{\\n  \\\"findings\\\": [\\n    {\\n      \\\"id\\\": \\\"Q01\\\",\\n      \\\"metric\\\": \\\"Dayside brightness temperature\\\",\\n      \\\"value\\\": \\\"342 +/- 22 K\\\",\\n      \\\"comparator_or_baseline\\\": \\\"Bare-rock expectation from no-redistribution model\\\",\\n      \\\"interpretation\\\": \\\"evidence_line_refs\\\": [\\\"L27\\\"]\\n    },\\n    {\\n      \\\"id\\\": \\\"Q02\\\",\\n      \\\"metric\\\": \\\"Heat transport efficiency (epsilon)\\\",\\n      \\\"value\\\": \\\"0.19 (+0.23 / -0.14)\\\",\\n      \\\"comparator_or_baseline\\\": \\\"0.0 for perfect no-atmosphere limit\\\",\\n      \\\"interpretation\\\": \\\"A non-zero redistribution parameter is favored, consistent with some day-to-night transport beyond a strict no-atmosphere reradiation limit.\\\",\\n      \\\"evidence_line_refs\\\": [\\\"L28\\\"]\\n    },\\n    {\\n      \\\"id\\\": \\\"Q03\\\",\\n      \\\"metric\\\": \\\"Bond albedo upper bound\\\",\\n      \\\"value\\\": \\\"<0.08\\\",\\n      \\\"comparator_or_baseline\\\": \\\"Higher-albedo reflective cases\\\",\\n      \\\"interpretation\\\": \\\"Energy-balance fits require a very low Bond albedo, implying the planet appears very dark in the context of the fitted thermal balance.\\\",\\n      \\\"evidence_line_refs\\\": [\\\"L29\\\"]\\n    },\\n    {\\n      \\\"id\\\": \\\"Q04\\\",\\n      \\\"metric\\\": \\\"15 um CO2 spectral band depth estimate\\\",\\n      \\\"value\\\": \\\"96 ppm\\\",\\n      \\\"comparator_or_baseline\\\": \\\"Flat-spectrum null\\\",\\n      \\\"interpretation\\\": \\\"A measurable 15 um band depth relative to a flat-spectrum null is reported, consistent with spectral structure from atmospheric absorption.\\\",\\n      \\\"evidence_line_refs\\\": [\\\"L30\\\"]\\n    },\\n    {\\n      \\\"id\\\": \\\"Q05\\\",\\n      \\\"metric\\\": \\\"Joint fit likelihood ratio (atmosphere vs no atmosphere)\\\",\\n      \\\"value\\\": \\\"7.4\\\",\\n      \\\"comparator_or_baseline\\\": \\\"1.0 baseline ratio\\\",\\n      \\\"interpretation\\\": \\\"When combining the phase-curve and spectral information, atmosphere-bearing models achieve a substantially higher likelihood than the no-atmosphere baseline.\\\",\\n      \\\"evidence_line_refs\\\": [\\\"L31\\\"]\\n    },\\n    {\\n      \\\"id\\\": \\\"Q06\\\",\\n      \\\"metric\\\": \\\"Preferred pressure scale in CO2-rich retrieval family\\\",\\n      \\\"value\\\": \\\"0.3-1.0 bar\\\",\\n      \\\"comparator_or_baseline\\\": \\\"Near-vacuum branch\\\",\\n      \\\"interpretation\\\": \\\"Within the CO2-rich family of retrievals, a moderate-pressure atmosphere range remains plausible compared with a near-vacuum alternative.\\\",\\n      \\\"evidence_line_refs\\\": [\\\"L32\\\"]\\n    }\\n  ],\\n  \\\"controls_or_null_results\\\": [\\n    {\\n      \\\"statement\\\": \\\"A pure no-atmosphere model cannot simultaneously match both phase amplitude and spectral band behavior.\\\",\\n      \\\"evidence_line_ref\\\": \\\"L35\\\"\\n    },\\n    {\\n      \\\"statement\\\": \\\"O2-rich atmosphere cases are not fully ruled out by current data.\\\",\\n      \\\"evidence_line_ref\\\": \\\"L36\\\"\\n    },\\n    {\\n      \\\"statement\\\": \\\"Degeneracies between composition, clouds/hazes, and circulation assumptions remain significant.\\\",\\n      \\\"evidence_line_ref\\\": \\\"L37\\\"\\n    }\\n  ]\\n}\"}",

  "id": "fc_073c6222a136b2710069907305e11881918e4385ef6762b700",

  "arguments": "{\"file_path\":\"output/claim_audit.json\",\"content\":\"{\\n  \\\"claims\\\": [\\n    {\\n      \\\"claim_id\\\": \\\"C01\\\",\\n      \\\"claim\\\": \\\"Jointly fitting the phase curve and spectrum favors atmosphere-bearing models over a strictly airless (bare-rock) interpretation for TRAPPIST-1 b.\\\",\\n      \\\"strength\\\": \\\"moderate\\\",\\n      \\\"evidence\\\": [\\n        {\\n          \\\"quote\\\": \\\"| Joint fit likelihood ratio (atmosphere vs no atmosphere) | 7.4 | 1.0 baseline ratio | Atmosphere-bearing models better explain combined data products |\\\",\\n          \\\"line_ref\\\": \\\"L31\\\"\\n        },\\n        {\\n          \\\"quote\\\": \\\"- A pure no-atmosphere model cannot simultaneously match both phase amplitude and spectral band behavior.\\\",\\n          \\\"line_ref\\\": \\\"L35\\\"\\n        },\\n        {\\n          \\\"quote\\\": \\\"The dataset provides meaningful evidence against a strictly airless interpretation for TRAPPIST-1 b, but atmospheric composition and pressure remain uncertain enough that follow-up spectroscopy is essential.\\\",\\n          \\\"line_ref\\\": \\\"L53\\\"\\n        }\\n      ],\\n      \\\"caveat\\\": \\\"Model assumptions and parameter degeneracies mean that the preferred explanation is not unique, and follow-up spectroscopy is needed to reduce uncertainty.\\\"\\n    },\\n    {\\n      \\\"claim_id\\\": \\\"C02\\\",\\n      \\\"claim\\\": \\\"The retrieved heat redistribution implies non-zero day-to-night transport, inconsistent with the perfect no-atmosphere limit.\\\",\\n      \\\"strength\\\": \\\"moderate\\\",\\n      \\\"evidence\\\": [\\n        {\\n          \\\"quote\\\": \\\"| Heat transport efficiency (epsilon) | 0.19 (+0.23 / -0.14) | 0.0 for perfect no-atmosphere limit | Non-zero redistribution is favored |\\\",\\n          \\\"line_ref\\\": \\\"L28\\\"\\n        },\\n        {\\n          \\\"quote\\\": \\\"2. A non-zero redistribution parameter implies transport beyond an immediate bare-rock reradiation limit.\\\",\\n          \\\"line_ref\\\": \\\"L41\\\"\\n        }\\n      ],\\n      \\\"caveat\\\": \\\"Quantitative posteriors for redistribution depend on retrieval assumptions, including circulation and opacity priors, and may shift with different modeling choices.\\\"\\n    },\\n    {\\n      \\\"claim_id\\\": \\\"C03\\\",\\n      \\\"claim\\\": \\\"Spectral structure around 15 um, including an estimated CO2-band depth, is consistent with atmospheric absorption rather than a flat-spectrum null.\\\",\\n      \\\"strength\\\": \\\"tentative\\\",\\n      \\\"evidence\\\": [\\n        {\\n          \\\"quote\\\": \\\"| 15 um CO2 spectral band depth estimate | 96 ppm | Flat-spectrum null | Spectral structure is consistent with atmospheric absorption |\\\",\\n          \\\"line_ref\\\": \\\"L30\\\"\\n        },\\n        {\\n          \\\"quote\\\": \\\"3. Spectral structure near 15 um provides composition-sensitive evidence, especially for CO2-rich scenarios.\\\",\\n          \\\"line_ref\\\": \\\"L42\\\"\\n        }\\n      ],\\n      \\\"caveat\\\": \\\"Weak spectral features can be biased by stellar variability and instrument systematics, so the inferred band structure requires cautious interpretation.\\\"\\n    },\\n    {\\n      \\\"claim_id\\\": \\\"C04\\\",\\n      \\\"claim\\\": \\\"Atmospheric composition and pressure are not yet well constrained, and further observations are needed to resolve degeneracies and strengthen night-side constraints.\\\",\\n      \\\"strength\\\": \\\"strong\\\",\\n      \\\"evidence\\\": [\\n        {\\n          \\\"quote\\\": \\\"The dataset provides meaningful evidence against a strictly airless interpretation for TRAPPIST-1 b, but atmospheric composition and pressure remain uncertain enough that follow-up spectroscopy is essential.\\\",\\n          \\\"line_ref\\\": \\\"L53\\\"\\n        },\\n        {\\n          \\\"quote\\\": \\\"- Night-side constraints are weaker than day-side constraints in the current dataset.\\\",\\n          \\\"line_ref\\\": \\\"L50\\\"\\n        },\\n        {\\n          \\\"quote\\\": \\\"5. Remaining degeneracies motivate broader wavelength coverage and repeated observations.\\\",\\n          \\\"line_ref\\\": \\\"L44\\\"\\n        }\\n      ],\\n      \\\"caveat\\\": \\\"Because multiple atmospheric scenarios (including O2-rich cases) are not fully ruled out and modeling degeneracies remain significant, conclusions about specific compositions should be treated as provisional.\\\"\\n    }\\n  ]\\n}\"}",
  "call_id": "call_CWDIR1WUv4cYYaH5CEqMQVKk",
  "name": "write_file",

}\n[tool-call]\n{
  "id": "fc_073c6222a136b2710069907305e1208191ae268097ec833133",
  "type": "function_call",
  "status": "completed",
  "arguments": "{\"file_path\":\"output/public_summary.json\",\"content\":\"{\\n  \\\"headline\\\": \\\"JWST phase-curve data hint that TRAPPIST-1 b may not be completely airless\\\",\\n  \\\"plain_language_summary\\\": \\\"TRAPPIST-1 b is a small, rocky planet that orbits extremely close to a cool, red (M-dwarf) star. Because the planet receives intense starlight and is likely tidally locked, a major question is whether it can hold onto any atmosphere at all. In this study, researchers used the James Webb Space Telescope (JWST) to watch the planet through its orbit with the MIRI instrument, measuring how its infrared heat changes with orbital phase (a \\\\\\\"phase curve\\\\\\\") and looking for subtle spectral structure near a carbon-dioxide (CO2) feature around 15 micrometers. When the thermal phase information and the spectrum are analyzed together with retrieval models, the combined fit is better for atmosphere-bearing scenarios than for a bare-rock, no-atmosphere case. The inferred heat redistribution is also non-zero, which is consistent with some day-to-night energy transport. However, important uncertainties remain: different compositions (including O2-rich atmospheres) are not fully excluded, and modeling assumptions, stellar variability, and instrument systematics can affect weak spectral features. The results therefore provide evidence against a strictly airless interpretation, but they do not yet pin down the exact atmospheric composition or pressure, motivating additional JWST observations and broader wavelength coverage.\\\",\\n  \\\"what_is_new\\\": [\\n    \\\"JWST/MIRI phase-curve spectroscopy is used to jointly constrain heat transport and atmospheric composition.\\\",\\n    \\\"A combined phase-curve + spectral fit favors atmosphere-bearing models over a simple bare-rock null model.\\\",\\n    \\\"A spectral structure near 15 um (often linked to CO2) is reported as consistent with atmospheric absorption.\\\"\\n  ],\\n  \\\"why_caution_is_needed\\\": [\\n    \\\"The analysis relies on retrieval models, and assumptions about circulation, clouds/hazes, and opacities can change the inferred parameters.\\\",\\n    \\\"Weak spectral signals may be affected by stellar variability and instrument systematics, complicating interpretation.\\\",\\n    \\\"Night-side constraints are weaker than day-side constraints, leaving key aspects of the energy balance less certain.\\\",\\n    \\\"Some alternative atmospheric scenarios (such as O2-rich cases) are not fully ruled out by current data.\\\"\\n  ],\\n  \\\"glossary\\\": [\\n    {\\n      \\\"term\\\": \\\"Phase curve\\\",\\n      \\\"definition\\\": \\\"A measurement of how a planet’s brightness changes through its orbit, revealing how heat is distributed between day and night sides.\\\"\\n    },\\n    {\\n      \\\"term\\\": \\\"Brightness temperature\\\",\\n      \\\"definition\\\": \\\"The temperature a blackbody would need to have to emit the observed infrared brightness; it is a way to summarize thermal emission.\\\" \\n    },\\n    {\\n      \\\"term\\\": \\\"Bond albedo\\\",\\n      \\\"definition\\\": \\\"The fraction of incoming starlight reflected back to space across all wavelengths; low Bond albedo means a very dark, absorbing planet.\\\" \\n    },\\n    {\\n      \\\"term\\\": \\\"Retrieval model\\\",\\n      \\\"definition\\\": \\\"A statistical framework that compares physical models to data to infer atmospheric properties (like composition and pressure) and their uncertainties.\\\" \\n    },\\n    {\\n      \\\"term\\\": \\\"15 um CO2 band\\\",\\n      \\\"definition\\\": \\\"An infrared wavelength region near 15 micrometers where carbon dioxide can absorb strongly, potentially imprinting a spectral feature in emission.\\\" \\n    }\\n  ],\\n  \\\"open_questions\\\": [\\n    \\\"What atmospheric composition (CO2-rich, O2-rich, or something else) best explains the data once degeneracies are reduced?\\\",\\n    \\\"What is the true surface pressure range, and does it remain stable under the star’s irradiation over long timescales?\\\",\\n    \\\"How much do stellar variability and instrument systematics contribute to the apparent 15 um spectral structure?\\\",\\n    \\\"Will repeated phase-curve observations produce consistent evidence for non-zero heat transport and atmospheric signatures?\\\"\\n  ]\\n}\"}",
  "call_id": "call_X5vyDAJSFNJFvVbwSp63mGXx",
  "name": "write_file",
  "parsed_arguments": null
}\n
